instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Whats up everyone, love you guys over at Rossman Repair Group, I have been working up the courage to start offering logic repairs to my customers (own a small repair shop) and your videos and knowledge have helped me work up to the point where I am actually doing some repairs, and have actually been successful in repairing a few, imagine that!

Anyhow, it is great to be a part of this awesome community, and I can't wait to start helping people get their items fixed at a more affordable rate!

So here is what I got going on!  (Please bear with me as I still feel slightly stoopid with schematics and understanding how the board actually works, but I learn quick ;-)

I've got a Macbook Pro 13" Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board with no backlight.

The LCD connector was partially melted off so I have already replaced that, hoping that would be it, but of course not.  

From what I can tell there is NO <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, which I believe based on the schematics that is what goes into the LED Driver and powers the Backlight Enable?

The <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> is not enabling if it has 12v on the <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN</SIGNAL> pin is that correct?
I am getting the 12v at the <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> but it is not making it to <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> which is the <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> Resistor.  Hope I am doing ok on this.

I am not sure what to do, and the only other question I have is this, does this board need to be powered on with the keyboard or do I need to power it on with power pads in order for the backlight voltage to appear?? Because if so, I am not doing that, and only have the board plugged in alone without anything else while testing.  

I have put the board back in the unit and it still displays an image, but still no backlight!

I really appreciate what everyone does here and I spent about 5 hours yesterday trying to figure this out on my own, with videos/brdview software.  I just think I need a little more teaching before I can repair these in a respectable time limit, because I just cant spend this much time on a board haha..

Thanks for reading, and I eagerly await the knowledge!

David Rainer
Computer Booter

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
"there is NO <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
I have put the board back in the unit and it still displays an image"
How do you get image then???
Where did you check that?

Post <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> voltages here...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Just was watching Louis' video on his repair, and he found a short to ground off the <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> resistors, well I found one too at <CAPACITOR>C8359</CAPACITOR> which is the <SIGNAL>IC2_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> line, I just removed it and the short is still there, so I guess that means I need to check the rest of those Capacitors in the line?? I am working on that, and I will also get the <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> voltages right now.

"there is no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>"  I guess that means I am wrong about that statement, sorry about that.. still learning. but I know 5v is missing all around the backlit driver and <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> resistors... unless the screen needs to be plugged in to get those??  Will report back soon, thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
I was thinking you reffer to <RESISTOR>R8320</RESISTOR> voltage.
5V must pass through <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> before goes there.
Should be there few seconds at least, when you here chime; even without LCD.

Remove <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> and see where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: Thanks for the help, I actually found that it was shorted at <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> and then read your comment, :-)   I removed it and the short is gone... So I'll need to replace that resistor and the capacitor I removed unecessarily...  Ill need to find the part from a donor board.... I need to replace these for the BKLT enable to reach the screen and test it right?  I hope this is all hahaaaa but it WAS fun!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
A resistor can't short anything to ground.
I asked you where the short remains...
It is on the side of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>?
I think yes, pin15 of it.
So you must change the chip...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
So, the Capacitor I removed was shorted to ground <CAPACITOR>C8359</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_ICL</SIGNAL>, when I removed that, the pads were both shorted to ground.  So you recommend I remove <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> which I did, that removed the short, or are you saying that its not a short, but maybe I misunderstand...  I replaced <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> and I still have no backlight...

Ok I will try a new chip, ill have to order one unless this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board has the same IC

I really appreciate the time you are taking to help me, so thank you again!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
A short on pin15/<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> will appear on <CAPACITOR>C8359</CAPACITOR> through <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> too.
If remove that resistor, short will stay on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> only; not anymore visible from <CAPACITOR>C8359</CAPACITOR>.
Is that I told you to check...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Thank you for bearing with me, (this newb) I now have a <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> voltage after replacing the <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> but no backlight.. I have ordered x2 LED Driver chips from your site, and I hope after replacing it things will be different haha, is there anything else I should check before receiving the new chip?? I do believe that the cap <CAPACITOR>C8359</CAPACITOR> destroyed the LED driver as a similar cap in Louis' video did as well.

I am still getting 12v on both pin 3/4 on <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> which I understand means it is not switching over either?? Sorry I dont quite understand, but from what Louis said in the video, this should be 12v on pin 4, and about 5-6v on pin 3 in order for the backlight to operate, is that correct?

I will replace the LED driver and test again. I love learning this and have learned a lot by watching the videos and am honestly amazed at the support and response you are giving to people... I appreciate it!

David

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: I will check the resistance from pin 15 to ground at the LED Driver today, I have already ordered more LED driver IC's from your site, but ill continue to try and learn and understand how the logic is working for my own, and my customers benefit!  The <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight repair the Louis' did is practically the same as this one, and near the end of the video he finds out that the cap for <SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> had blown the donor LED Driver that he had installed, so after removing that cap, he replaces the LED Driver for the second time, and then he gets backlight.  So I will check the resistance to ground at pin 15 of the LED IC, which I am assuming will be almost 0 and then once I get the LED driver I will replace it!  Fun fun fun!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: Ok haha that did not go well, after I replaced the LED Driver, since im a n00b, it ended up burning up the LCD connector for some reason, and now it would need a new screen since replacing that connector is practically impossible, unfortunately I will not be repairing this MacBook!  I'll stay on the 29$ forum fee for a while though even though I rarely get logic level repairs, because Rossman deserves my sub, thanks for all you do!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: The LCD cable can easily be replaced on retina LCDs!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 39305"]The LCD cable can easily be replaced on retina LCDs![/QUOTE]

oh yeah? I never knew as the older models it was a PAIN, ill have to remember this for next time as I already gave the customer her computer back.  She is going through her insurance to get it replaced but might still have it repaired, depending on insurance.  Thanks, and ill have another board that has missing Wifi and loud fans to repair here soon.  Second attempt at repairing it.  Ill start a new post
